results.title: U.S. Says 1,500 Americans Remain in Afghanistan as Evacuation Enters Final Days
results.abstract: The State Department is frantically trying to track down U.S. citizens. Tens of thousands of Afghan allies will all but certainly be left behind.
results.byline: By Lara Jakes and Michael Levenson
des_facet: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
org_facet: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

results.title: In First Interview From Jail, an Upbeat Navalny Discusses Prison Life
results.abstract: Russian political prisoners today are subjected to “psychological” pressure, said the opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny, who is forced to watch state TV for more than eight hours a day.

multimedia.caption: Aleksei A. Navalny in May. “Imagine something like a Chinese labor camp,” he said of his prison experience, adding, “There is constant control and a culture of snitching.”
multimedia.copyright: Dimitar Dilkoff/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

multimedia.caption: Aleksei A. Navalny in May. “Imagine something like a Chinese labor camp,” he said of his prison experience, adding, “There is constant control and a culture of snitching.”

results.title: Rejecting Covid Inquiry, China Peddles Conspiracy Theories Blaming the U.S.
results.abstract: A new wave of disinformation follows President Biden’s order for the United States to investigate the origin of the pandemic, including the possibility of a lab leak in Wuhan.
results.byline: By Austin Ramzy and Amy Chang Chien

multimedia.caption: A lab at Fort Detrick in Maryland. Beijing is peddling groundless theories that the United States is the source of the coronavirus.
multimedia.copyright: Andrew Harnik/Associated Press

results.abstract: Abbas Karimi, who was born without arms, eventually made it to the U.S. and realized his dream of competing internationally.

results.title: ISIS Branch Poses Biggest Immediate Terror Threat to Evacuation in Kabul
results.abstract: An Islamic State affiliate that is a sworn enemy of both the Taliban and the United States threatens a large-scale attack against the mission at the airport.
org_facet: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

multimedia.caption: Outside the international airport in Kabul on Wednesday. The biggest immediate threat to the Americans and the Taliban as the United States escalates its evacuation is ISIS-K, the Islamic State’s affiliate in Afghanistan.
multimedia.copyright: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times

results.title: Budding Resistance to the Taliban Faces Long Odds
results.abstract: For now, the fighters have merely two assets: a narrow valley with a history of repelling invaders and the legacy of a storied mujahedeen commander.

results.abstract: He was once a faceless spokesman for an insurgent group. On Wednesday, Zabihullah Mujahid, a top Taliban official, held forth in the seat of government.

results.title: Few Women Ascend Japan’s Corporate Ladder. Is Change Finally Coming?
results.abstract: Only 6 percent of board seats at Japanese companies are held by women. After years of unkept promises, these businesses are now facing pressure both at home and abroad to diversify.

multimedia.caption: Naomi Koshi, a lawyer who serves on two corporate boards, said she first understood the inequality in Japan in 2000, when she graduated from college.
multimedia.copyright: Shiho Fukada for The New York Times

results.title: How Many People in Afghanistan Need to be Rescued? The Number Remains Elusive.
results.abstract: U.S. officials are reluctant to provide an estimate of the one number that matters most in their stream of evacuation updates.

results.title: Under Taliban Rule, Life in Kabul Transforms Once Again
results.abstract: Though the streets are quiet, Kabul residents describe a struggle to make ends meet in a reeling economy where banks and government offices are closed, and uncertainty reigns.

results.title: Chinese Citizen Who Documented Wuhan Outbreak Falls Ill in Prison Hunger Strike
results.abstract: Zhang Zhan was sentenced to four years for videos about failures in handling the virus. She now weighs less than 90 pounds, her former lawyer says.
results.byline: By Amy Chang Chien and Austin Ramzy
des_facet: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

multimedia.caption: Zhang Zhan in Wuhan, China, last year. She declined to appeal her conviction, telling her lawyers that she refused to acknowledge the validity of the legal process used to imprison her.
multimedia.copyright: Melanie Wang, via Associated Press

results.title: Montenegro Pledges to Stamp Out a Deadly Trade: Cigarette Smuggling
results.abstract: Investigators and journalists were killed while trying to expose smugglers. Now the country is cracking down on a trade it once protected.

multimedia.caption: A warehouse at the port in Bar, Montenegro. Cigarettes shipped from here with false documents cost European countries billions of dollars in tax revenue.

results.title: Biden Falls Short on Pledge for U.S. to Be the World’s Vaccine ‘Arsenal,’ Experts Say
results.abstract: Congress appropriated $16 billion to ramp up Covid-19 countermeasures, but a new report found that the Biden administration had spent very little of it on expanding vaccine manufacturing capacity.

multimedia.caption: A woman receiving a shot of the AstraZeneca vaccine, distributed by Covax, in Nepal this month. The Biden administration donates doses through Covax, the international vaccine effort.

results.title: 2 U.S. Representatives Try to Explain Unauthorized Visit to Kabul
results.abstract: Representatives Seth Moulton and Peter Meijer said they could not get answers on the evacuation from the Biden administration, so they went to Afghanistan to see for themselves.
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

multimedia.caption: Representative Seth Moulton, Democrat of Massachusetts, in 2019. “This is one of the most complicated operations that the U.S. military has done in decades,” he said in a interview on Wednesday.

results.title: Chicago will require city workers to be vaccinated, the mayor says.
results.abstract: The mandate requires municipal workers — including teachers and other public school employees — to be fully vaccinated by Oct. 15 unless they obtain medical or religious exemptions.

results.title: Teenage Aviator Aims to Be Youngest Woman to Circle the Globe Solo
results.abstract: Zara Rutherford, 19, left Belgium last week and plans to complete her journey by early November. Bad weather may be the biggest obstacle.

multimedia.caption: Zara Rutherford began her journey in Belgium last week and plans to return there on Nov. 3 after soaring over 52 countries on five continents.

results.title: Two House members secretly flew to Kabul on an unauthorized oversight mission.
results.abstract: Biden administration officials said the trip by Representatives Seth Moulton and Peter Meijer had wasted resources needed to help evacuate people in Afghanistan.

multimedia.caption: Gathering outside the airport in Kabul this week. Biden administration officials argued that the two House members’ trip there diverted badly needed resources from the evacuation effort.
